Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: From Statistical to Worst-Case Learning: A Unified Framework

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning theory studies the extent to which meaningful patterns can be extracted from data. Two popular frameworks for the analysis of learning algorithms are statistical learning and worst-case online learning. Recent developments suggest that these two seemingly disparate frameworks are, in fact, two endpoints of a spectrum of problems which can be studied in a unified manner. The goals of this project are (a) to understand learnability and to develop efficient algorithms for a spectrum of problems corresponding to various probabilistic and non-probabilistic assumptions on the data; (b) to extend learnability results to encompass performance criteria beyond the classical notion of regret; (c) to understand the inherent complexity of reinforcement learning and to develop novel algorithms inspired by the learnability analysis; (d) to study learnability in settings with imperfect or partial information, and to understand algorithmic implications of dealing with uncertainty.

Algorithms that extract patterns from data are becoming increasingly important in the information age. However, classical methods that assume a "static" nature of the world are unable to capture the evolving character of data. Recent advances in learning theory have been on the dynamic interaction between the world and the learner. Being able to tailor the algorithms to particular assumptions on data is arguably a central goal of learning theory. The intellectual merit of this proposal includes the development of a unified theoretical framework, increasing our understanding of what is learnable by computers. Advances in this direction will likely facilitate the development of more intelligent systems, having a positive impact on technology. The interdisciplinary nature of the project will likely increase collaboration between Computer Science and Statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and co-authors developed a unified framework for online learning that encompasses a spectrum of problems, from the classical setting of learning from training samples to prediction of arbitrary (possibly adversarial) sequences. In addition to theoretical results, the PI and co-authors developed an systematic approach to deriving new prediction methods. These findings already yielded new computationally efficient learning methods for a variety of difficult problems, such as prediction in social networks and contextual bandits with large policy classes. The latter problem is ubiquitous in modern applications of ad placement, dynamic treatment regimes in medicine, and other sequential problems with limited feedback. The findings of this project, reported in nearly 20 research papers, made fundamental connections to several other fields of study, such as Probability Theory, Statistics, and Optimization.

Broader imacts of the work include the development of several new courses ("Statistical Learning and Sequential Prediction" at the University of Pennsylvania and "Online Methods in Machine Learning: Theory and Applications" at MIT). Notes for these courses are available online. The topic of this project facilitated the professional development of a postdoctoral researcher, and encouraged a further focus on machine learning within the University of Pennsylvania. The outcomes of the project are likely to have a long lasting impact both in the theoretical study of machine learning, and in real-world applications. As such, the outcomes are likely to have an impact on society and technology.
